awd_titl_txt: The development of the global engineer: Effects of ethnographic investigations on students' design decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to characterize how the content and depth of students? ethnographic
investigations impact their design decisions, specifically as students define the problem,
develop design requirements and engineering specifications, select concepts, and develop
validation studies. Successful design solutions must be practical in the cultural context in which
they will be used. While all engineering students are not able to participate in a substantial
cultural immersion experience, a clear understanding of how these skills develop, the
challenges students face, and how design ethnography affects later stages of design will
facilitate the development and integration of these techniques into engineering design courses
as well as the development of validated metrics to evaluate proficiency in design ethnography.

The broader significance of this research is to provide undergraduate engineering students with
pedagogy, curricula, and experiences that teach them ethnographic and co-creation skills. The
result will be design solutions that better address user needs for emerging global technological
challenges. The ability of engineers to conduct ethnographic studies and use the data to make
effective design decisions will facilitate the development of innovative, practical, and
implementable solutions that address this century?s global challenges.

por.por_cntn:
The context in which a design solution will be employed is becoming increasingly critical for engineering designers to consider because of current and future global technological challenges (e.g., health, clean water, energy). Growing in popularity, design ethnography is a methodology for developing products that are well adapted to context and culture. Design ethnography represents a set of tools used to gain a deep understanding of stakeholder behaviors and priorities through observing stakeholders in their native environments and interacting with stakeholders through semiformal and formal interviews. Design ethnography performed in stakeholders’ native environments provides a host of advantages over traditional market research methodologies. A key advantage is its ability to discover needs and problems that are not otherwise obvious to the designer or even the stakeholder.

While some engineering programs have incorporated design ethnography methods and processes into curricula, studies have shown that successfully engaging with stakeholders and incorporating the information gathered through these interactions into the design process is challenging.  Prior research on students’ understanding and use of data generated through stakeholder interactions during the design process showed that students do not always interact with stakeholders successfully. The goal of our research was to explore how students and novice designers employ design ethnography techniques during design, where and how they struggle to successfully implement these techniques, and how one might support students in the process to facilitate success.

To accomplish these goals, two primary studies were conducted. In the first, eight capstone design teams were tracked as they used design ethnography techniques during a semester long design project. Four group interviews were conducted with each team throughout the semester and pre-/post-semester surveys were also used. Results showed that teams perceived stakeholder interactions to be useful when they pre-specified a goal for the interaction, interacted with a subject matter expert, and ceded control of the decision making process to the stakeholders. Students found interactions less useful when information gathered was highly variable or when information was not directly applicable to the design decision at hand (aspects that are quite common with design ethnography data). We also found that teams had unique approaches to stakeholder engagement during the course as a function of the stakeholders involved, project type, and their perceptions of the importance of stakeholder engagement. The factors identified in the analysis elucidate the specific areas in which students require additional support during design decision-making. These factors point to the need for structures to assist in the extensive information processing requirements associated with human-centered design.

In the second study, an interactive design task was developed wherein participants spent six hours defining product requirements and engineering specifications for an assigned problem statement. Participants were provided with access to multiple design ethnography data sources (stakeholder interviews and observations) and qualitative and quantitative data were collected from overhead video camera footage, screenshots of participants’ computers, audio/video recordings of stakeholder interviews, participants’ notebooks, post-task information use surveys, requirements evaluations (by stakeholders), and post-task interviews with participants. Results showed that stakeholder evaluations of requirements and the level of tailoring of the requirements to both the design context and stakeholders were highly correlated to the number of distinct information sources used and moderately correlated to participants’ dependency on particular information sources. These results indicate that designers should consult a larger number of information sources when designing (e.g., consider a more diverse set of opinions/information sources) and should strive to avoid becoming fixated on any one particular set of information sources during design. Furthermore, an in-depth exploration of participants’ information gathering behavior during the design task elucidated specific strategies and processes that may explain why some participants were more successful than others.

The findings from this work illustrate how design ethnography techniques are employed by novice designers and the challenges novice designers face while implementing design ethnography. As a result of this research, we have a better understanding of how design ethnography techniques should be taught within the undergraduate curriculum and how design tools can be developed to help novice designers implement this complex skillset. Future work will focus on the development and validation of this pedagogy and these tools.
